title: 107_hr5241
content: The Act titled "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2002" amends the Public Health Service Act by adding a new section on Lifespan Respite Care. This section includes findings and purposes related to respite care services. Congress finds that millions of individuals in the United States provide care for family members with chronic illnesses or disabilities, including children living with relatives due to parental inability or unwillingness to care for them. Additionally, many children with disabilities live with foster care parents. Approximately 6,000,000 children in the United States live with relatives due to parental inability or unwillingness to care for them. An estimated 165,000 children with disabilities live with foster care parents, and nearly 4,000,000 individuals with mental retardation or developmental disabilities live with their families. Additionally, around 25 percent of the Nation's elders rely on others for daily needs, and approximately 600,000 Americans die at home each year after extensive family caregiving. Approximately 42 percent of individuals in the United States needing daily living assistance are under age 65. Family caregivers provide services that would cost $200 billion annually if replaced with paid workers. This role, mainly taken on by women, is personally rewarding but can lead to emotional, physical, and financial hardships due to insufficient resources. Approximately 75 percent of family caregivers are women, facing emotional, physical, and financial hardships. They often struggle to find information on available respite care programs, which are insufficient and primarily cater to lower-income populations and the elderly. Limited programs also face challenges in recruiting trained respite workers. The purposes of this title are to encourage States to establish State and local lifespan respite care programs, improve respite care information dissemination, provide respite care services to family caregivers, and promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery. The purposes of this title are to improve and coordinate the dissemination of respite care information and resources to family caregivers, provide, supplement, or improve respite care services, promote innovative approaches to respite care delivery, support evaluative research on effective respite care services, and promote the dissemination of research findings. The purpose of this section is to support evaluative research on effective respite care services that alleviate caregiver strain and promote the dissemination of results and information related to respite care delivery and caregiver training. "Definitions are provided in Section 2802." The term 'condition' in this title includes Alzheimer's disease, developmental disabilities, mental retardation, physical disabilities, chronic illness (such as cancer), behavioral and emotional conditions, cognitive impairments, situations at high risk of abuse or neglect, situations where a child's parent is unavailable, traumatic brain injury, and other conditions determined by the Secretary. The term 'condition' in this title includes Alzheimer's disease, developmental disabilities, mental retardation, physical disabilities, chronic illness (such as cancer), behavioral and emotional conditions, cognitive impairments, situations at high risk of abuse or neglect, situations where a child's parent is unavailable, traumatic brain injury, and other conditions designated by the Secretary. Eligible recipients include State agencies, public entities operating statewide, nonprofit organizations operating statewide, political subdivisions with a population of at least 3,000,000 individuals, and recognized State respite coordinating entities. The term 'family caregiver' refers to individuals who provide care to family members, with specific criteria for eligibility including operating on a statewide basis, being a private nonprofit organization capable of statewide operation, a political subdivision with a population of at least 3,000,000 individuals, or a recognized State respite coordinating agency with demonstrated abilities in working with other agencies and understanding respite care and family caregiver issues. The term 'family caregiver' encompasses unpaid family members, foster parents, or other unpaid adults providing in-home care for individuals with special needs. Lifespan respite care involves a coordinated system of accessible services for family caregivers regardless of age or special need. Respite care is defined as planned care to provide temporary relief to caregivers. The term 'lifespan respite care' refers to a coordinated system of community-based services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. Respite care is defined as planned or emergency care provided to give temporary relief to caregivers when needed. The term 'special need' pertains to the specific requirements of individuals of any age who require care. The term 'special need' refers to the particular needs of individuals requiring care due to a condition to meet basic needs or prevent harm, when the family caregiver is unable to provide care. "SEC. 2803. LIFESPAN RESPITE CARE GRANTS AND COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS." The section aims to expand respite care services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and enhance access and quality of services to reduce caregiver strain. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible recipients for this purpose, in collaboration with relevant agencies. In collaboration with relevant agencies, the Secretary will ensure coordination of respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs through grant applications. Each eligible recipient must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant or cooperative agreement under this section, including a description of their understanding of respite care and family caregiver issues, capacity for involving family members, caregivers, and care recipients, and collaboration with other agencies. The eligible recipient must describe their capacity for involving family members, caregivers, and care recipients, as well as collaboration with other agencies. Additionally, they must provide a description of the population of family caregivers, their respite care needs, and existing services available to them. The curr_chunk focuses on assessing the population's respite care needs, existing services, coordination methods, and recruitment/training programs for respite care workers and volunteers. The curr_chunk outlines the provision of respite care services, worker/volunteer training programs, and collaboration with other related services or programs. The curr_chunk outlines collaboration and coordination of respite care activities with other services, participation of population in planning, and maximizing use of funds. The curr_chunk focuses on how proposed respite care activities will utilize federal, state, and local resources, improve coordination of services for family caregivers, and identify criteria for assisting individuals with special needs. The applicant's plan aims to improve coordination and distribution of respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. It includes criteria for identifying eligible caregivers, monitoring quality and safety of services, and ensuring respite care workers possess necessary skills. The expected results from the proposed plan are also outlined. The applicant's plan includes screening respite care workers and volunteers, ensuring they have necessary skills to care for the care recipient. It also outlines expected results from respite care activities and procedures for evaluation. Additionally, there are assurances for maintaining confidentiality of care recipient and family caregiver records. The Secretary will establish a review panel to assess applications. The Secretary will establish a panel to review and evaluate applications for respite care grants, making recommendations for approval. The Secretary will establish a panel to review and evaluate respite care grant applications and make recommendations for approval. Grants or cooperative agreements will be awarded based on the panel's recommendations, with priority given to applicants focusing on implementing or enhancing lifespan respite care statewide. The Secretary is restricted from awarding funds without approval to eligible recipients. The Secretary prioritizes applicants showing the greatest likelihood of implementing or enhancing lifespan respite care statewide. Grant funds must be used for developing respite care, providing services to meet needs, and evaluating effectiveness. The Secretary awards grants for developing respite care services, coordinating delivery, and evaluating effectiveness. Recipients can subcontract with public or nonprofit agencies. Grants are awarded for a maximum of 5 years and can be renewed. The Secretary awards grants for respite care services for up to 5 years, with the possibility of renewal. Funds must supplement, not supplant, other available federal, state, and local funds. The Secretary will award a grant to establish a National Resource Center on Lifespan Respite Care. The Center will maintain a national database, provide training and assistance to respite care programs, and offer information and educational programs to the public. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this title.
